newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish beet producers seek 1997/98 price rise.
newsitem.headline: Turkish beet producers seek 1997/98 price rise.

text.p: Turkey's 1996/97 sugar beet harvest has ended with an improved crop that will allow for more exports, but farmers told the government on Tuesday they will need a large rise in purchase prices in 1997/98.
"The harvest has been completed and better results will be obtained," said Selahattin Hun, general manager of state sugar refineries Turkseker, which operates 25 of the 28 refineries in Turkey.
He said Turkey would achieve increassed output in 1996/97 and Turkseker planned further exports after selling 50,000 tonnes earlier this month to a local trader.

"We have to calculate our stocks carefully. We will definitely have some surplus and some 50,000 tonnes more is planned for exports," he told Reuters on the sidelines of the general assembly of Pankobirlik, a union of cooperatives representing 450,000 growers in Turkey.
Turkseker earlier said some 300,000 tonnes could be earmarked for exports in 1997.
A Pankobirlik report presented at the meeting said the union expected 2.05 million tonnes of sugar production in 1997/98, up from 1.85 million tonnes in 1996/97.
It said consumption was expected to reach 1.95 million tonnes in 1997/98, up from 1.9 million 1996/97.
A Pankobirlik official said the total beet area was 422,000 hectares in 1996/97 with an expected beet output of 12.981 million tonnes, up from 312,000 and 10.989 million a year ago.
Industry Minister Yalim Erez reiterated the sugar production figure of 1.85 million tonnes for 1996/97 and told the meeting Turkey would not be a sugar importer again.
But Pankobirlik president Mehmet Bayrakli said that unless beet farmers were satisfied with beet purchase prices for 1997/98 Turkey would face a shortfall and imports could follow in calendar 1998.
"The government first gave a good base price last year, but they failed to keep their promise of increasing the base price in line with inflation," he said.
"If the government makes the same mistake this year our sugar production will not suffice."
The government usually announces beet purchase prices in the spring.
Turkey imported about 500,000 tonnes of sugar in calendar 1996, up from 400,000 tonnes a year earlier, the Pankobirlik report said, adding no imports were expected in calendar 1997.
In 1994/95 and 95/96 farmers opted for what were then more profitable crops such as grains, vegetables and cotton.
This reduced overall beet area by 25 percent and led to imports.
The Pankobirlik report suggested a rise in the purchase prices to 11,500 lira per kg for 1997/97 from 4,400 lira.
Erez would not say what kind of rise the government was planning for this year, but told farmers, "The mistakes made in previous years will not be repeated this year."

He said payments to cover Turkseker's debts to farmers for beet purchases from the 1996/97 campaign would be completed in February. "All payments totalling 55.18 trillion lira from last year's purchases will be paid in February," he said.
